an7.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an7.1:4.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an7.1:5.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.
an7.1:5.3: It’s when a mendicant desires material possessions, honor, and to be looked up to. They lack conscience and prudence. They have wicked desires and wrong view.
an7.1:5.4: A mendicant with these seven qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.
an7.1:6.1: A mendicant with seven qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an7.1:6.3: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t desire material possessions, honor, and to be looked up to. They have conscience and prudence. They have few desires and right view.
an7.1:6.4: A mendicant with these seven qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”
